name: 1-[(Z)-2-{3-[2-(2,4-dinitrophenyl)ethenyl]phenyl}ethenyl]-2,4-dinitrobenzene
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-783

name: 1-[(Z)-2-{3-[2-(2,4-dinitrophenyl)ethenyl]phenyl}ethenyl]-2,4-dinitrobenzene
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-783
Reason: The target compound has a polyaromatic structure with three benzene rings, which contributes to a higher melting point due to the planar structure of the system and strong intermolecular pi-pi interactions. Basic benzene has a melting point of 5.5. Each nitro group (-NO2) is a strong electron-withdrawing group that increases intermolecular forces due to its inductive effect and capability to form strong hydrogen bonds; this would add approximately +40 degrees to the melting point per nitro group. As there are six nitro groups in total, their overall contribution would be +240. The vinyl groups (C=C) link the benzene rings together which would contribute an additional stability to the molecule, increasing the melting point. This effect may add around +5 per vinyl linkage. There are two vinyl linkages present in the structure, which sums to +10. However, these adjustments are approximations and the actual presence of such functional groups in conjugated and symmetric systems might yield less incremental change than in aliphatic systems due to resonance stabilization and symmetry making the molecule more rigid and hence, increasing the melting point. Considering the cumulative effect of all the functionalities present, we can make the prediction.

name: 1-[(Z)-2-{3-[2-(2,4-dinitrophenyl)ethenyl]phenyl}ethenyl]-2,4-dinitrobenzene
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-783
Reason: The target compound possesses a conjugated polyaromatic structure with three interconnected benzene rings, which is known to elevate melting points due to the extended planarity and reinforced intermolecular pi-pi stacking interactions. The basic melting point of benzene is 5.5. The presence of six nitro groups significantly enhances the melting point due to their electron-withdrawing nature and ability to participate in intermolecular interactions, such as hydrogen bonding, despite no hydrogen being available to form traditional hydrogen bonds; they add polar character and rigidity to the compound. Each nitro group can be estimated to raise the melting point by +40 degrees, contributing an increase of 240 when combined. The molecule also includes two vinyl linkages which help to stabilize the conjugated system, likely making the molecule more rigid and increasing the melting point by about +5 degrees for each linkage, adding up to +10 degrees. As consequence, a total estimated increase in melting point can be predicted by summing the individual contributions.

name: 1-[(Z)-2-{3-[2-(2,4-dinitrophenyl)ethenyl]phenyl}ethenyl]-2,4-dinitrobenzene
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-783
Reason: The target compound is a complex aromatic molecule with multiple substitutions. The backbone is a polyene structure with three phenyl groups, enhancing rigidity and π-π interactions. - Each dinitrophenyl group has a strong electron-withdrawing effect due to the nitro groups, significantly increasing intermolecular forces and therefore the melting point. Estimation for each dinitrophenyl group: +70°C. - The central double bonds in the polyene structure may marginally raise the melting point due to increased rigidity and molecular weight, but since they are conjugated with the aromatic system, the effect will be less pronounced than aliphatic systems. Estimation for each double bond: +5°C. - Basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C, serving as the starting baseline for our predictions. The combined effects of the substituents should be additive, but with a diminishing return as the molecular size and complexity increase.
